column2: Question
column3: Why / Details
column6: Answer

column2: What is the expected Authorization header format? Is it 'Authorization: Bearer <token>'?
column3: OpenAPI securitySchemes declares an apiKey named 'JWT Authorization' — ambiguous and nonstandard.
column4: Clarify header name and scheme; supply sample curl with header
column6: The authorization header indeed should be 'Authorization: Bearer <token>'. We have a document (97-0007798) that I will ensure is attached with these answers
column7: Document 97-0007798 is being approved and released shortly

column2: Who is the owner / point of contact for the API and where will updates be posted?
column3: Who to contact, where to look for documentations, new versions, breaking changes.
column6: That will be me (Szymon Zieba), as the owner of the API.

column2: Is there a canonical base URL and separate staging/sandbox endpoints?
column3: Required to configure CI, tests, and polling targets.
column6: Unfortunately,  we do not host staging endpoints for our system.

column2: Which result fields are arrays/objects that must be JSON-encoded into a CSV cell (e.g., values, details)?
column3: User requested arrays encoded - confirm which
column6: I am not sure I correctly understand the question, but measurements are under the parameter set field of a TimeSeries response. Each parameter set will have differing number of measurements due to differing subsystems

column2: Structure of 'values' array: names and types of elements (timestamp, value, type, quality?)?
column3: Needed to choose columns or JSON cell
column6: values field will generally hold either a boolean or a number value. While we support arrays and strings for value, no subsystem used in SETL will emit these

column2: What is token lifetime and refresh strategy? Can we get a permanent token with no expiry?
column3: Affects caching and refresh logic
column4: e.g. access_token expires 15m, refresh_token 30d, Never expires
column6: Current PSS requirements that we are beholden to do not allow permenant tokens. The access_token is configured to expire after 5 minutes, I cannot find a refresh_token expiry time, but there is a session idle time of 30minutes

column2: Where is the Keycloak instance running (hostname, realm, client) and how to obtain client credentials? (client id / secret)
column3: Needed to request JWTs and configure automated pulls
column4: e.g. auth.example.com, realm: vems, client_id: southeatern, client_secret: <secret>
column6: The Keycloak instance is hosted on the same PCE as the DMS UI, and can be accessed using the same base url `/auth`.

column2: Are there audience/claim requirements in JWTs (scope, roles, issuer)?
column3: If server validates specific claims, need to craft requests accordingly
column6: You will get your JWT from Keycloak, so this is not something you need to be concerned with.

column2: What grant types are allowed for machine-to-machine access?
column3: Impacts implementation (client_credentials vs. auth code)
column6: For auth, we operate on a process where a system authenticates with client credentials for the initial login, then future requests are managed using JWT.

column2: Which endpoints require elevated roles (dms_admin) vs standard (dms_user)?
column3: Plan least-privilege service token
column6: See earlier response

column2: Are there 'modified' or 'created' fields for results to incremental-pull instead of full snapshot?
column3: Enables incremental sync
column6: There are modified and created fields on results, although typically they will be found to be equal, as most results are written only once.

column2: Can the same result be returned multiple times across different queries/polls?
column3: Need dedupe logic (id + timestamp)
column6: This will depend on the structure of the request, but it is possible. Depending on how bounds are written, this can be avoided without special handling

column2: Is there a formal API contract (machine-readable) delivered and maintained (OpenAPI hosted)?
column3: Helps codegen and CI checks
column6: The OpenAPI Spec provided should be able to output the underlying json. This json code can then be fed into an OpenAPI code generator for directly relevant client code.

column2: If we hardcode CSV headers, confirm canonical column list per component_category (e.g., GuideTyre): which fields are required?
column3: Can we hardcode headers, can we get canonical list
column6: CSVs are available only through the UI. There may be an API endpoint claiming to supply CSVs in the spec, but this endpoint is not functional and should be disregarded.

column2: Are there quality/flag fields in results (e.g. status, confidence) and allowed ranges?
column3: Important for filtering/alerts
column6: All parameter sets come with a status and a confidence field. Status should be "OK" if there is no issue with a measurement. Confidence is more difficult to explain as it is based on a range of factors and cannot be easily boiled down to a rubric like "+- 0.5mm".

column2: How many images are taken for the measurements?
column3: Typical total size of images taken per train pass (MBytes / GBytes)
column6: VIS will take approx. 5000 images, but most other systems will take 1-4 images per measurable component. As such, VIS may require 1.5 GB, but other systems may only use 15 MB for their reporting requirements.

column2: Expected data rates per subsystem (results/sec)
column3: Typical payload size impacts storage and processing
column6: Results are typically reported in one go to our DMS, after the offline time of a pass

column2: Character encoding for CSV and JSON (UTF-8 expected?)
column3: Avoid importing and encoding problems
column6: As we have not specified a specific encoding, I would suggest UTF-8, but will confirm.

column2: Are transient errors retryable, and which HTTP codes indicate retry vs fail if any?
column3: Help to implement robust retry/backoff. Help to implement retry strategy that avoids hammering the API, handles transient failures, respects server signals, and prevents synchronized retry storms.
column4: E.g. retry only on transient errors: 429, 502, 503, 504, timeout/network glitches. Do NOT retry 4xx client errors (400,401,403,404) except 429. if Retry-After header present, wait that long (seconds or HTTP-date).
column6: Suggested guidelines seem valid. Note that 5xx errors may be a proxy issue and require us to logon and restart the proxy. The data will still be available, however.

column2: Are alerts delivered to /alerts endpoint or are those POST-only for ingestion?
column3: OpenAPI shows /alerts POST - need direction/usage. Is there a GET endpoint?
column6: Alerts endpoint is deprecated, having never been used for its intended purpose. It was only developed to ingest data, but the source of the data will never send it to the DMS.

column2: Define 'events', 'alerts', 'notifications': semantics, relationships, lifecycle, retention?
column3: We need to map these with our business logic and business events / alerts / notifications
column6:
events' are events within the scope of system operation, we primarily use them as part of system health monitoring
'notifications' are references to notable events (indicating whether they were newly raised or resolved) or alarm detection (if one or more alarms were detected within a pass)
'alerts' should be ignored, as they are a deprecated feature.

column2: Do alerts reference result ids or pass ids? Field mapping required.
column3: To correlate alerts with measurements
column6: See above

column2: Provide full example payloads for /results/timeseries/search request and response including values/details arrays that are not there in the spec already
column3: We need exact JSON / CVS to validate client
column6: Samples for each subsystem present will be provided alongside this answer sheet

column2: Exact types and nullable behavior for each top-level 'result' field (string,int,float,bool,array)
column3: Needed for CSV typing and nullable handling
column6: The specification should already state the types of fields and which are nullable.

column2: Are ids stable unique ids across time (id vs component_id vs pass_pass_id)?
column3: To use as primary keys when merging datasets
column6: Yes, most ids are flake ids, with the exception of pass_pass_id which will be a UUID, repetition, while technically possible, is highly unlikely

column2: What semantics for limit/offset vs cursor? Are there max limits and defaults?
column3: OpenAPI mentions limit/offset but no defaults/max
column6:
Default offset is 0, and can be set to any value. If offset is > than the number of results available, no results will be returned.
Default limit is 20, with a max value of 500. Offset can be used with limit to fetch results in excess of the 500 max, you can view offset as picking from what point to fetch results from.

column2: Are there any API rate limits, soft/hard quotas, or burst rules?
column3: Important for scheduler/backoff and retries
column6: There are API Rate Limits, see info below: <add rate limits>

column2: For 'results' items: confirm full set of top-level keys (id/component_id/component_category/values/details/etc.)
column3: Needed to flatten to CSV columns
column6: Please clarify. In short, csv is not available except in UI.

column2: Canonical example response for /results/timeseries/search (full schema + types)?
column3: We have examples but need authoritative sample for all fields
column6: Sample data to be sent via email.

column2: How long are results and alerts retained on the DMS? Can retention be configured per-site?
column3: Storage planning and re-pull window
column6:
Results and Events are currently retained forever. In the future, this will be changed to be retained according to the projects requirements.
Note that profiles and images are cleaned up on a regular basis, if access to these are required. Typically, profiles are stored for ~6 months and images for ~1 month, though our contract may require different retention periods and this will need to be confirmed

column2: Some OpenAPI 'content' objects are elided (?) ? provide full schemas or examples for those endpoints?
column3: Many endpoints lack inline examples
column6: Please clarify. Need examples of end points.

column2: Many schema fragments are '?' ?  request complete component schemas for result DTOs
column3: Needed for code-gen
column6: Please clarify. Need examples.

column2: Are term searches case sensitive? Are string matches exact, wildcarded or tokenized?
column3: Affects filter design and expected results
column6: Search terms are indeed case sensitive, as they operate on exact matches

column2: What are valid field names for component_queries and is it strictly arrays of strings or objects allowed?
column3: We need to build query builder to match expected input
column6: More time required for checking.

column2: Provide full grammar/semantics for SearchFilterDTO (and meaning of and/or/not/is_null/contains/range/term). Which operators are supported per-field?
column3: Search DSL is underspecified in docs; needed for correct queries
column4: Examples for nested fields and arrays
column6: I will try to provide supporting documentation to help here, it is a complex field

column2: What's the maximum for 'limit'? OpenAPI mentions 500?
column3: Avoid accidental large / invalid requests
column6: Correct, maximum limit is 500, for any results beyond 500, offset should be used (e.g. first 500 results is offset 0, next 500 is offset 500)

column2: Exact semantics for 'query': supported operators (term, range, and/or/not, contains, is_null)?
column3: OpenAPI lists many but behavior needs examples
column6: I will try to provide supporting documentation to help here, it is a complex field

column2: What fields are searchable in timeseries/search and which are indexed for range vs term?
column3: Important to craft performant queries
column6: I thought this was in the spec, but I will provide the list. All fields are indexed, but some query formulations may result in less performant responses than others, even when the final filter is the same

column2: Are tokens scoped to site/subsystem (multi-tenant) or global? Explain scoping model.
column3: Impacts how token is restricted and which data it can access.
column6: Tokens are scoped to projects

column2: Contact and SLA for API issues and request for schema fixes/clarifications?
column3: Vendor support?  Point of contacts?
column6: Szymon is the owner.

column2: Do you provide a sandbox or test credentials and sample dataset for integration tests?
column3: We currently have no access - need to plan integration
column6: We currently do not provide a sandbox, but the user accounts provided thus far are the read only dms_user accounts and should be safe to use

column2: Which fields are expensive on server side (total=true, deep nested includes)? Mark them to avoid frequent calls.
column3: Performance
column6: total=true can be expensive if the total amount of data is very large. It is recommended to be restrictive with the filtering. Includes are already done within our system, rather than being done dynamically.

column2: Are timestamps milliseconds since epoch (UTC) and is timezone consistent?
column3: OpenAPI uses milliseconds but confirm and request timezone policy
column6: Just need confirmation / further clarification of what is stated in the spec

column2: Define exact capabilities for dms_user/dms_admin (list of allowed endpoints/actions)
column3: Necessary for automation token roles
column6:
dms_user is a read only account that can access any read endpoint
dms_admin has all the permissions of dms_user, and in addition may edit vehicles, trains and parameter details.

column2: Can tokens be restricted to site/subsystem scope or only role-based?
column3: Least privilege tokens may be site-scoped
column6: Only role based, though tokens are in practice scoped to sites due to the keycloak instance being hosted on the system directly.

column2: Is there an API versioning policy? How new versions and  how possible breaking changes are communicated?
column3: Detect breaking changes,  make sure our poller doesn?t silently break.
column6: Every release of the API is versioned, even if the specification doesn't change. At this time, changes are purely additive and if there were a breaking change, it would be communicated through the semantic versioning used.

column2: How are breaking changes and OpenAPI updates communicated? Is there versioning in the URL or header?
column3: Planning for upgrades and compatibility tests.
column6: There is versioning available, but it is not currently in use. At this time, breaking changes will not occur as the changes are purely additive.

column2: Is export atomic (consistent snapshot) for large queries or can results change during export?
column3: Affects data consistency
column6: Export without upper bounds on time cannot be guaranteed to be atomic, as new data will shift previous data in the store.

column2: How are images/profiles referenced (paths, presigned URLs, auth needed)? Can we have file access? If yes how? Auth method?
column3: /files endpoints exist - need access method
column6: `/files endpoint accepts a filetype (profile/image) and a flake id (available in results).
column7: SFTP forwarder can be setup for exporting the images/profile to customer provided SFTP server. Frequency of export can be configured. Due to PSS requirement, we cannot provide incoming access to the product.

column2: Is there any other access to the data, other than API
column4: E.g. direct databasa access, providing database views (read-only)
column6: No

column2: Does the API record access logs with token info and can we retrieve logs for troubleshooting?
column3: Helps debugging and compliance
column6: Our API logging system uses the syslog of the host VM for storage. Currently this is not externally accessible.

column2: For historical imports, can we request arbitrary time ranges or are there archive constraints?
column3: Data migration planning
column6: For results, at this time, we do not clean out measurements, so any arbitrary time range can be used.

column2: Are file downloads protected by same JWT and are tokens required per-download?
column3: Affects file fetch logic
column6: All API endpoints require a JWT to validate authorization requirements.

column2: Is there a way to subscribe to schema changes or a changelog for OpenAPI updates?
column3: Prevent silent breakages
column6: This is not currently a feature of the DMS

column2: Is there a recommended canonical CSV export schema (server-side / results/export)?,/results/export/search exists - need sample headers
column3: Need specification of the returned CSV formats and / or concrete examples
column6: As mentioned above, this endpoint is deprecated. If a CSV is required, it is recommended to make use of the UI "Export CSV" button

column2: Max payload size per response (bytes) and any streaming alternative?
column3: Large arrays may be truncated
column6:
Don't really have a max payload. 
No. Alternative export options are abvailable as paid for options.

column2: Does /results/export/search produce server-side CSV with exact columns? If so, what are headers?
column3: Might save client-side processing
column6: Server-side CSV export is deprecated

column2: Are there stable set of keys present in results or can they vary per component type?
column3: If variable, CSV must be tolerant
column6: Need more clarifcation.

column2: For component-specific parameters (e.g., GuideTyre specific keys) is there a features->schema mapping?
column3: Needed to pre-define CSV columns per component_category
column6: Need more clarifcation.

column2: Are component_id and pass_pass_id globally unique or namespaced per site/subsystem?
column3: Affects dedupe strategy
column6: Results already have a unique flake id assigned, but if you need more, a composite key of pass_pass_id, component_id and subsystem_id is recommended, in case the same component can be measured by multiple subsystems.

column2: Is IP allowlisting used for production access? If so, provide ranges.
column3: Deployment networking
column6:
Yes, we do have IP whitelisting in appliance firewall and OS firewall. 
We have different ranges for different network, internal product management, TCM, PDB network. This can be updated to accomodate customer's network range for external access.

column2: Are there monitoring / health endpoints and metrics we can scrape? (uptime, status, queue lengths)
column3: Operational visibility
column6: I don't believe this is currently a feature, pass statistics and subsystem statistics can support on uptime

column2: How are missing fields represented (absent vs null vs empty)?
column3: CSV needs consistent empty cell rules
column6: Could be absent, returned as null or even just empty.

column2: Does 'total' require an extra expensive query, is it accurate in large datasets?
column3: Affects performance; may need separate call
column6: We do not currently use total estimates, so the counts are always exact. It is a less expensive query than an actual data request, but it can sometimes be slow.

column2: Do they provide per-token or per-IP limits and returned headers for remaining allowance?
column3: Enables adaptive throttling
column6: Rate Limits are not per-token or per-IP at this time

column2: Do 'values' arrays represent time series ordered by timestamp and guaranteed monotonic?
column3: CSV flattening depends on order
column6: Need more clarifcation.

column2: Are component_queries always arrays of strings or can they include objects/ids?
column3: Clarify structure of component_queries
column6: previously answered.

column6: Not at this time

column2: Any required headers beyond Authorization (e.g., Tenant-ID, X-Request-ID)?
column3: Needed for routing/multitenancy and tracing
column6: Not at this time

column3: Use to page results safely
column6: Sorts are applied in order

column3: Large exports might be treated specially
column6: No

column2: Should saved filenames/timestamps use UTC or local timezone?
column3: Consistency for cross-system correlation
column6: Unless your system is designed to operate outside your home country (like ours are), you can use local timezones.

column2: Does range filtering on pass_online_timestamp use inclusive/exclusive bounds? Confirm semantics.
column3: Edge cases near boundary timestamps
column6: Range filters have options for both

column2: Minimum TLS version and cipher policy required by server?
column3: Security and client compatibility
column6: v1.2 or v1.3, see image to right for cipher policy

column2: What's the versioning policy? URL versioning or header? How to track breaking changes?
column3: Important for upgrade planning
column6: There is header versioning, but it is not currently in use

column2: Is there any push capability (webhook/stream) instead of polling?
column3: Prefer push for low-latency
column6: We utilise a SignalR endpoint for notifications, but this is not all results.

column3: Affects TLS client setup and security

column2: Is there a health/metrics endpoint (Prometheus metrics or /health) we can poll to monitor availability?
column3: Operational monitoring
column6:
No
System health can be monitored using the events endpoint (searching for open "Critical" or "Error" events), or by making requests to the subsystem endpoints as these endpoints include a field "Ready To Measure" that evaluates if there is an open downtime.

column2: Which top-level keys in each result are scalar and which are complex? Which must be encoded as JSON cells in CSV (e.g., values, details)?
column3: User requested CSV flattening; need canonical list per component category

column2: Do result objects have a fixed schema per component_category (GuideTyre vs Wheel) or can top-level keys vary arbitrarily?
column3: Determines CSV header strategy (hardcoded vs dynamic)
column6: Answered previously.

column2: Can the same result id reappear across different queries (reprocessed/updated)? If results can be updated, provide last_modified or version field.
column3: If updates occur we need upsert logic instead of append-only

column2: Are there any PII/retention/GDPR considerations for measurement payloads?
column3: Compliance requirements

column2: Which HTTP error codes are transient and safe to retry, and recommended backoff strategy?
column3: e.g. 429, 502, 503, 504 - require exponential backoff
column6: We do not implement a back off strategy. For 429, we have a request limit in order of minutes. 502-504 are server errors.

column2: List exact capabilities per role (dms_user, dms_admin). Which endpoints or methods are restricted to admin?
column3: Security & least privilege planning

column2: Provide a non-sensitive sample JWT (not a real key) that decodes to show claims for expected tokens so we can mock verification.
column3: Allows offline dev and unit tests

column2: How frequent is the schema for results modified? Any changelog or schema registry? Any backward-compatible rules?
column3: Helps automation and data contract enforcement
column6: Schema is stable except for deprecated end points which will be removed.

column2: There are mixed naming conventions (snake_case, camelCase, @Definition.*). Which canonical naming convention should clients use?
column3: Prevents query mismatches

column2: How to express nested path names in queries (dot notation vs underscore vs @Definition.k)? The docs reference multiple styles.
column3: Inconsistent examples: '@Definition.component_category' vs 'component_category' vs 'details_threshold_value'

column2: What is the maximum allowed 'limit' and do larger values impact server performance? Is 500 enforced server-side?
column3: Docs mention default max 500 — confirm hard limit and error codes
column6: 500 is enforced. Larger values definitely impact server performance.

column2: Does total=true cause an expensive server-side count? Should we avoid total for frequent polling?
column3: If expensive, we will not set total in normal polls

column2: Does the API perform role checks via claim names (e.g., roles in 'realm_access') and which role strings are used?
column3: We must include correct roles or group membership for endpoint access

column2: If we find schema bugs, how quickly will Siemens supply corrected OpenAPI and patched API?
column3: Project timeline and risk mitigation
column6: This will vary depending on the scale of the issue. Will depend also on what change orders are in place.

column2: Sort fields mention 'max 5 fields' — confirm behaviour for nested fields and stability of sort for pagination.
column3: To perform deterministic paging, sort must be stable. e.g., '-pass_online_timestamp'

column2: Is there a push alternative (webhooks, message queue, streaming API like SSE or MQTT) for near-real-time notifications?
column3: Polling is inefficient for low-latency use cases

column2: Who is the Siemens support contact and SLA for outages/bugs? Any escalation matrix for API defects?
column3: Project management and planning
column6: Post-handover, this will need to go through Customer Service locally and will be fed to relevant people.

column2: Provide test accounts with dms_user and dms_admin roles and sample tokens so we can validate permissions.
column3: Necessary for role-matrix testing
column6: We will supply user accounts when they come through. Admin will be supplied in the future.

column2: Provide sandbox URL, test data, sample JWTs and test client credentials for integration testing.
column3: We currently have no access — must test in isolation

column2: Provide typical payload sizes for /results/timeseries/search responses (bytes and number of elements) for normal and peak loads.
column3: Helps sizing storage and network
column6: There is not really a typical payload size, this is heavily influenced by the use (eg 100 results will require less than 500)

column2: Do you provide Postman/Newman collections, or sample curl examples for all endpoints including authentication flows?
column3: Speeds our integration testing

column2: If timezone is not UTC, provide server timezone or ISO timestamp formats and DST behavior.
What TLS minimum version/cipher requirements are enforced? Do we need to support TLS1.3 only?
column3: Cert and client compatibility planning
column6: Answered previously

column2: Are roles tenant-specific (per site) or global? Should service tokens be scoped per-site?
column3: Affects token scoping and access control
column6: Answered previously

column2: If webhooks exist, what signing/verification method is used (HMAC, JWT)?
column3: Ensure webhook source authenticity
